posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked:
We are designing a robot cart and would appreciate any suggestions before we start building. It is based on the Spectrum robot cart and we are wanting something fairly simple. The handle supports are supposed to be removable by taking out a few bolts. It will be on casters.

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/f410f7e995b85158d72f348f/w/a675db82c70600b1ead6eab6/e/109574ef7afb89c352b1867c

posts.name: Elliott Kaye
posts.cooked: It says that we do not have permission to view the design.

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: Sorry. Trying to figure that out.

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: I supposedly made the link public. Please let me know. It is assembly “Robot 2”

posts.name: Ainesh Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: The biggest recommendation I would make is consistently labeling your parts and features, it makes it much easier when you start to manufacture and whatnot. Other than that it looks really good!

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: Thanks. We’re trying to implement one of the part numbering featurescripts but haven’t wuite settled on one.

posts.name: Brian Wagg
posts.cooked: I don’t see them modeled at the moment, but be sure to pick some decent size casters/wheels for your cart. We have some 5" casters on ours that we’ve been happy with, but if your local events tend to have really obnoxious cable guards/parking lots/other major bumps, I could see opting for even larger. I certainly wouldn’t want to go smaller (IMO at least).

posts.name: James O’Leary
posts.cooked: I’d add another shelf under the robot, one thing we’ve run into is room for bumpers and larger tools we might need in queue, it’s also just good for general use. I’d also change the tube that the robot sits on to more of a hashtag(i’m assuming y’all are running swerve) so then you have good clearance on each wheel regardless of frame size. It’ll also give you better support around the robot since you’ll have all 4 sides supported

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked:
Can you describe the hashtag layout. I’m not sure what you’re suggesting.

Thank you

posts.name: James O’Leary
posts.cooked:
image 736×727 73.8 KB something like this, i just noticed the green 4” is prob for that but i’d do something like this if possible but up to you

image 736×727 73.8 KB

image 736×727 73.8 KB

posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked:
our team has a incredibly low cart which is nice at times and sometimes its terrible, for on you can work on the robot easily because parts can rest on the floor like a worktop, this can backfire with lazy pit mechanics though if they don’t clean up during matches or before the robot is back. I’ve seen some teams with taller carts that work wonderfully, just depends on what you want.

the other thing is cart storage is incredibly important, some teams like bumpers with them at all times, have a good tool kit (Ethernet cable, Allen wrenches maybe even a battery beak if you want. have a spot for a second battery on the cart as well, just in case you need it for practice or hopefully not; a match.

sorry didn’t mean to reply to you meant to reply to the topic
